data.title: 32Bit Linux VS Code Distributed With libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so Built For 64Bit amd64
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 12.04 LTS [_**arch=i386**_]

Steps to Reproduce:

1. _[Download and install latest 32 Bit version of vscode for Debian Linux](http://bit.ly/vscode32Bit)_.
2. Launch vscode and install the '_[Language Support for Java(TM) by Red Hat](http://bit.ly/redhatjavaextn)_'  extension.
3. Restart vscode.

On restart, error messages appear; reporting that components required for the '_[Language Support for Java(TM) by Red Hat](http://bit.ly/redhatjavaextn)_' extension, failed to initiate.

_[Reading and analyzing the stacktrace in vscode's log files](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/978956/library.libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so.not.found.0.stacktrace.txt)_, a "_Library 'libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so' not found!_" error entry identifies the root cause. That library was tracked down to '[user.home.dir]/.vscode/extensions/redhat.java-0.3.0/server/config_linux/org.eclipse.osgi/45/0/.cp/lib/junixsocket-native-common-2.0.4.jar'.

This is a listing of the native libraries contained in 1.12.0's '_junixsocket-native-common-2.0.4.jar_'...

```
lib/x86_64-MacOSX-gpp/
lib/x86_64-MacOSX-gpp/jni/
lib/x86_64-MacOSX-gpp/jni/history.xml
lib/x86_64-MacOSX-gpp/jni/libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.dylib
lib/x86_64-MacOSX-gpp/jni/libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.jnilib
lib/amd64-Linux-gpp/
lib/amd64-Linux-gpp/jni/
lib/amd64-Linux-gpp/jni/libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so
lib/amd64-Linux-gpp/jni/history.xml
```
Notice that the only Linux library distributed in the 32Bit 1.12.0 release, is the one built for the amd64 [_**64Bit**_] architecture! It is therefore incompatible with the 32Bit Linux on which 32Bit versions of vscode are meant to be installed.

It was obvious to me after seeing the above files in the 1.12.20 jar, that the system â€” _knowing that it is running on an i386 OS_ â€” is attempting to locate a library built for an i386 architecture. But there isn't one  distributed in the 1.12.20 release. Hence the "_Library 'libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so' not found!_" error. 

I _[downloaded the junixsocket-parent-2.0.4 source from here](https://github.com/kohlschutter/junixsocket/releases/tag/junixsocket-parent-2.0.4)_ and built it on my 32bit Ubuntu machine, using maven.

I then replaced the original amd64 64Bit '_junixsocket-native-common-2.0.4.jar_' with the 32Bit one that I built _[from the source](http://bit.ly/redhatjavaextn)_. Details of the steps I took _[are listed here](http://bit.ly/javavscode45)_.

On my Ubuntu 12_04 LTS machine, my freshly-built 32Bit [_**i386**_] replacement '_libjunixsocket-native-2.0.4.so_' library and jar files, perfectly resolved _[the defect described in detail here](http://bit.ly/vscodejava45)_.

data.title: Cannot make the completion item to overwrite further than the current identifier/token
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Win10 Creators

Steps to Reproduce:

1. write `field(;FirstValue){}`
2. request completion after open paren (
3. get returned `SecondValue;SecondValue` with span from `(` to `)`
4. `;FirstValue` does not get removed

Expected: `field(SecondValue;SecondValue)`
Actual: `field(SecondValue;SecondValue;FirstValue)`

It looks to me that you can't replace characters which don't belong to the current token even if you specify a TextSpan which encompasses the other characters. Is it bug in our code or this feature is missing?

|standard|shinnn|0.2.3|
|code-spell-checker|streetsidesoftware|1.1.0|
|JasmineSnippets|xabikos|0.2.1|;


---


I have configured the following in keybindings.json

```
    {
        "key": "ctrl+shift+a",
        "command": "workbench.action.toggleActivityBarVisibility",
        "when": "inZenMode"
    }
```

The expectation is to be able to use the shortcut when in ZenMode to toggle the activity bar.
But the shortcut is only active **outside** ZenMode!

Also, with each toggle, the icons for VSTS (work items, pull requests etc). get duplicated within the status bar!

data.title: Unable to write settings on VSCode 1.12

- VSCode Version: 1.12 (latest today May 5th 2017)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install latest VSCode (1.12) as always (sudo dpkg -i code-.....)
2. File -> Preferences -> Color Theme
3. Choose a new one (Solarized dark, Dark+, ...)
4. Message from VSCode: 
" Problem setting theme: Unable to write settings. Please open User Settings to correct errors/warnings in the file and try again."

So, I open settings.json, modify manually the entry and it works, but, in version 1.11, I could change the theme (depending on the environment light) or install an icon theme without error.

Not too urgent but thanks for giving it a look.

Best regards.

data.title: Automatic insertion of parens doesn't interact nicely with completions, results in duplicated characters
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Assume the following code (cursor is where the `|` is):

```dart
foo() {
}


main() {
  fo|
}
```

Completion is returning `foo()`. If the user continues to type `o(` then the `o` and `(` are "subtracted" from the completion client-side by Code (it doesn't send another request to the completion provider). This works great; however since typing the `(` auto-inserts a `)` if the user then uses the completion, they will end up with:

```dart
main() {
  foo()) // <-- two closing parens
}
```

There's an animation showing a slightly different version or this at https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/issues/285

I can't see how the completion provider can fix this, since Code has taken over completion at this point (it's filtering and reducing the completion text client-side). I think the best thing would be for Code to subtract any auto-inserted characters from the end of the completion text in the same way it's removing the typed characters from the start.

Eg, when the user types the `(`:
1. Filter the completion list by the `(`
2. Remove the `(` from the completion text to be inserted, and adjust the range accordingly
3. Because a character was auto-inserted after the cursor, subtract that character from the end of the insertion text (and adjust the range) if it's the same character

I think 1 & 2 already happen, I think 3 would make sense to fix this.

data.title: UI: Use em dash (â€”) as window title separator on macOS
data.body: Most macOS apps (like Terminal.app) use em dash (`â€”`) instead of en dash (`-`) as window title separator. I suggest VS Code use em dash for better consistency.

data.title: CheckJS marks global variables and text in comments
data.body:
_From @sbowler on May 4, 2017 20:2_

I'm not quite sure this is the right repo for this, but here goes. Using the latest released vscode I've tried to use the new checkJs compiler option. I'm not finding any way to mark global variables in client side code like lodash as valid so they are not flagged everywhere. Even better would be automatically reading them from ESLint config files, but that's another feature.

In addition it also seems to be scanning and marking items in jsdoc style comments as invalid like 
`* @param {float}`
"Cannot find name float"

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node#205_

data.title: workbench.action.navigate strange behaviour
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: MacOs Sierra

Hi, I tried to bind this commands : 
```
  {
    "key": "home",
    "command": "workbench.action.navigateLeft"
  },
  {
    "key": "end",
    "command": "workbench.action.navigateRight"
  },
  {
    "key": "pageup",
    "command": "workbench.action.navigateUp"
  },
  {
    "key": "pagedown",
    "command": "workbench.action.navigateDown"
  }
```

The two first (home & end) allow me to switch my active cursor to left and right panel.
But neither navigateUp or navigateDown seems to work correctly.

**First:** Here is a scenario, with following commands : 
- workbench.action.navigateRight (+some moves)
- workbench.action.navigateRight (+some moves)
- workbench.action.navigateRight (+some moves)
- workbench.action.navigateTop, but i'm stuck in file explorer
but as you can see, i'm unable to switch to the top "opened editor" panel with navigateTop
![switchpanel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599375/25738739/14f6fdda-317f-11e7-9ae6-f35fb53a93b5.gif)

**Second:** Another scenario, with following commands : 
- workbench.action.navigateRight (+some moves)
- workbench.action.navigateLeft (+some moves)
- workbench.action.navigateDown
- now i'm stuck in the terminal, none workbench.action.navigateXXX works anymore
![switchpanel2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599375/25739016/47ab6238-3180-11e7-98fb-adc2bd9f0f70.gif)

I don't find any other command allowing to go out of the terminal, or to switch between open editor and the explorer file list. Maybe i missed it and i can add command with conditions to allow me doing that.

My goal is to be able to work without touching my mouse. Which seems difficult without such functionality.

Thanks,

David

data.title: Feature request: Don't remove search results when text is changed?
data.body:
Currently, if I do a find in files, the results are listed on the left. As I then click each result to make a change I can edit the file. If this is something like a rename, it means that as soon as I edit the text, the result on the left dissappears. This makes it hard to work out how far down the list of search results I've got to.

Would it be possible to grey out the result (as it is no longer valid) instead of removing it completely?

data.title: Mark Completion Items with Command as MakesTextEdit
data.body:
Fixes #25998 
Fixes #25959

**Bug**
See #25998

**Fix**
A Completion item with a command should always be treated as if it may alter the current document
